The smiles have returned on the faces of industry players who are once again back in the black and busy meeting the rising global demand for the black gold which fell sharply while Covid-19 was raging. Against the backdrop of economic rebound post-pandemic, geopolitical tensions and capacity constraints, consumption of fossil fuel is showing no sign of relenting despite the global move towards energy transition. Companies are having their hands full supporting oil and gas majors in their exploration and production activities which have gathered considerable pace following the reopening of economies and the full resumption of business and daily activities.

Petroliam Nasional Bhd (#Petronas), which is seeking to establish a carbon capture and storage (#CCS) hub in Pahang, has inked a land rental agreement with #KuantanPort Consortium Sdn Bhd for the project. The hub, which is expected to have its first injection by 2029, is intended to play a key role in reducing carbon emissions for hard-to-abate industries locally and internationally. Petronas noted the location of the hub is ideal for an integrated CCS value chain and future growth, and is expected to create new economic opportunities and benefits for the surrounding communities. Petronas added the strategic move enables knowledge transfer with Kuantan Port, which has a strong track record in handling diverse cargo types, fostering regional trade growth and implementing modern logistics solutions. The national oil company has also tied up with the likes of #ExxonMobil and #Shell Malaysia to explore the development of other CCS projects and carbon sequestration hubs in the country, as it seeks to unlock Malaysiaâ€™s potential as a regional CCS solutions hub. According to reports, Petronas has allocated 20% of its annual capital expenditure (capex) from 2022 to 2026 for its overall decarbonisation efforts. ~ TheEdgeMalaysia & UpstreamOnline

Earlier this year, OSRL Responders from the Asia-Pacific region had the opportunity to conduct a joint inland fast river booming exercise with Petroleum Industry Of Malaysia Mutual Aid Group (PIMMAG) in Malaysia. In the event of an oil spill in Malaysia, PIMMAG will respond to the incident as a Tier 2 Oil Spill Response organization. OSRL, functioning as a Tier 3 OSRO, may also collaborate with PIMMAG to assist with incident response. To further develop the partnership between both entities, OSRL & PIMMAG decided to conduct joint exercises to strengthen coordination and facilitate knowledge exchange. Additionally, responders based in Singapore have limited exposure to inland operations due to the scarcity of suitable training facilities in the country - particularly rivers with fast flow rate. This led to the inception of joint inland exercises in Port Dickson, Malaysia in 2018 with PIMMAG. Following positive feedback from the previous responders that attended that training, OSRL decided to bring back the training exercise this year!
